{{EngvarB|date=September 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox book | name = The Invasion of 1910: With a full account of the Siege of London | image = File:TheInvasionOf1910.jpg | caption = First edition | authors = [[William Le Queux]]
[[Herbert Wrigley Wilson|H. W. Wilson]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United Kingdom | subject = | genre = [[Invasion literature]] | set_in = United Kingdom, 1910 | publisher = E. Nash | release_date = 1906 | media_type = Print (hardback) | oclc = 59567217 | wikisource = The Invasion of 1910 | external_url = http://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/36155 | external_host = [[Project Gutenburg]] }} '''''The Invasion of 1910''''' is a 1906 novel written mainly by [[William Le Queux]] (along with [[Herbert Wrigley Wilson|H. W. Wilson]] providing the naval chapters). It is one of the most famous examples of [[invasion literature]]. It is viewed by some as an example of pre-World War I [[Anti-German sentiment|Germanophobia]]. It can also be viewed as prescient, as it preached the need to prepare for war with Germany. ==Background== The novel was originally commissioned by [[Alfred Harmsworth]] as a serial which appeared in the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' from 19 March 1906. According to historian of Germany [[Richard J. Evans|Sir Richard Evans]], the paper built up "mass alarm" by dressing its London newspaper vendors as Prussian soldiers complete with [[pickelhaube]] helmet and placards showing maps of where the 'troops' would be next day.{{cite episode|title=The Riddle of the sands|series=In Our Time|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00bzdg4|minutes=36|date=12 June 2008|accessdate=6 March 2017}} The rewrite of the story, featuring towns and villages with large readership of the ''Daily Mail'', {{cite book | last = Eby | first = Cecil D. | year = 1988 | title = The Road to Armageddon: The Martial Spirit in English Popular Literature, 1870–1914 | publisher = [[Duke University Press]] | location = [[Durham, North Carolina]] | page = 33 | url = https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Vxwl2V9U5VwC&lpg=PP1&ots=cV4olDKgNp&dq=The%20road%20to%20Armageddon%3A%20the%20martial%20spirit%20in%20English%20popular%20literature%2C%201870-1914&pg=PA32#v=onepage&q=The%20road%20to%20Armageddon:%20the%20martial%20spirit%20in%20English%20popular%20literature,%201870-1914&f=false | isbn = 0-8223-0775-8 }} greatly increased the newspaper's circulation and made a small fortune for Le Queux; it was translated into twenty-seven languages, and over one million copies of the book edition were sold.{{cite web | last = Clarke | first = I.F. | title = Future-War Fiction: The First Main Phase, 1871–1900 | work = Science Fiction Studies | publisher = [[DePauw University]] | date = November 1997 | url = http://www.depauw.edu/sfs/clarkeess.htm | access-date = 14 August 2008| df=dmy-all}} The idea for the novel is alleged to have originated from [[Frederick Roberts, 1st Earl Roberts|Field Marshal Earl Roberts]], who regularly lectured English schoolboys on the need to prepare for war.{{cite book | last = Sladen | first = N. St. Barbe | title = The Real Le Queux: The Official Biography | publisher = Nicholson & Watson | location = London | year = 1938 }} To Le Queux's dismay, a pirated and abridged German translation (with an altered ending) appeared the same year: ''Die Invasion von 1910: Einfall der Deutschen in England'' translated by Traugott Tamm. In Le Queux's earlier novel, ''[[The Great War in England in 1897]]'', it is France which invades Britain as an implacable enemy. In that book's plot, German soldiers land in Britain as allies coming to help repulse the French invasion, and are welcomed as saviours. In between Le Queux's two disparate depictions of an invaded Britain, the [[Entente Cordiale]] of 1904 changed the diplomatic and military landscape. ==Outline== The book takes the form of a military history and includes excerpts from the characters' journals and letters and descriptions of the fictional German campaign itself. It is centred on an invasion by the Germans, who have managed to land a sizeable invasion force on the East Coast of England. They advance inland, cutting all telegraph lines and despoiling farmland as they go, and the British struggle to mount a proper defence, fighting a battle at [[Royston, Hertfordshire|Royston]]. The Germans eventually reach London and occupy half the city. A junior [[Member of Parliament (United Kingdom)|Member of Parliament]] declares that "Britain is not defeated" and organises a resistance movement, the "League of Defenders," despite harsh reprisals by the Germans and a severe lack of arms. The Germans seem unable to combat this and tighten their control of London and suddenly find themselves faced with a popular uprising. Eventually, a newly formed [[British Army]] marches to liberate London. The fictional war, however, is a stalemate since it appears that German forces have managed to occupy [[Belgium]] and [[the Netherlands]]. ==Agenda== The failure of the British government to prepare for a possible invasion is repeatedly mentioned, as is the phrase "they should have listened to Lord Roberts", along with many references to Roberts' patriotism. It is also pointed out that the invasion might have been counteracted more easily if every able-bodied man had had military training. Le Queux himself stated that one of his aims was to "bring home to the British public vividly and forcibly what really would occur were an enemy suddenly to appear in our midst". ==Film version== Le Queux's novel attracted the attention of the [[Gaumont Film Company|Gaumont Cinematograph Company]] in 1912, who planned to change the title to ''The Raid of 1915'' and to film two endings, one with Britain as the victor and one with Germany as the victor. The British satirical magazine ''[[Punch (magazine)|Punch]]'' suggested they show the Britain victorious version in Germany and the other version in Britain. The film was finished in 1913 but its release was delayed by the [[British Board of Film Censors]] and when it was finally released in October 1914 (three months after the start of [[World War I]]), it had again been retitled, to ''If England were Invaded''.{{cite book | last = Waller | first = Philip J. | title = Writers, Readers, and Reputations: Literary Life in Britain 1870–1918 | publisher = [[Oxford University Press]] | year = 2006 | pages = 9 | isbn = 0-19-820677-1}} ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080510191724/http://www.changingthetimes.net/bookreviews/invasion_of_1910.htm Review] {{DEFAULTSORT:Invasion of 1910, The}} [[Category:1906 British novels]] [[Category:Invasion literature]] [[Category:Novels first published in serial form]] [[Category:Works originally published in the Daily Mail]] [[Category:1910 in fiction]] [[Category:Invasions of England]] [[Category:British novels adapted into films]] [[Category:Literary collaborations]] [[Category:Novels set in the future]]

{{Italic title}} '''''The Sekhmet Hypothesis''''' was first published in book form in 1995 by Iain Spence.{{cite book| last1 = Spence | first1 = Iain| title = The Sekhmet Hypothesis| publisher = Bast's Blend| date = 1995| isbn = 9780952536505}} It suggested that pop trends of an atavistic nature could be analysed in relation to Timothy Leary's [[Interpersonal_circumplex|Interpersonal Circumplex Grid]]. It also suggested that major youth trends could be correlated to peaks in the 11 year solar cycle; this idea was later rejected by the author in 1999.Spence, Iain (2012). ''The Hare Hypothesis''. Bast's Blend. {{asin|B009E2YUJM}}. Chapter 1 - Does Society 'Dream' Youth Trends? The hypothesis was published in 1997 in the journal ''Towards 2012''{{cite journal |last=Spence |first=Iain |date=1997 |title=The Sekhmet Hypothesis |url=http://dreamflesh.com/projects/towards-2012/ |journal=Towards 2012 (Part 3 Culture and Language) |publisher=Unlimited Dream Company/Slab-O-Concrete |isbn=189986606X|accessdate= March 14, 2014}} and covered in 1999, in ''[[Sleazenation]]'' magazine.{{cite journal |last=Beale |first=Steve |date=1999 |title=1999 |journal=Sleazenation |publisher=Swinstead | issn= 1742-5506}} [[File:FrenchHippie.jpg|thumb|right|French [[hippie]] - the hypothesis suggests that atavistic youth trends can be viewed as recurring archetypal symbols.]] ==Origins of the hypothesis== The origins of the hypothesis can be traced back to [[Robert Anton Wilson]]'s book, ''[[Prometheus Rising]]'', in which Wilson makes a singular correlation between the symbol of the flower child with the mood of friendly weakness.{{cite book| last1 = Wilson | first1 = Robert Anton| title = Prometheus Rising| publisher = Falcon Press| page = 55| date = 1983| isbn = 9781561840564}} 'She/He is self-critical, shy, timid, easily led, "spineless," and always looking for somebody to Take Charge and Give Orders. The unearthly Angel, or in modern symbolism, the Flower Child'. Spence extended the comment into a study of various youth archetypes and linked in their behaviour to the four [[atavistic]] life scripts. The life scripts relate to each other with the following dialogue:{{cite book| last1 = Wilson | first1 = Robert Anton| title = Prometheus Rising| pages = 50 to 59|publisher = Falcon Press| date = 1983| isbn =9781561840564}}
Friendly Weakness - I'm not okay, you're okay Hostile Weakness - I'm not okay, you're not okay Friendly Strength - I'm okay, you're okay Hostile Strength - I'm okay, you're not okay
A diversified and holistic guide to the four life scripts was first introduced by Dr. [[Timothy Leary]] and three of his colleagues in 1951.{{cite book|last1 = Leary|first1 = Timothy|last2 = Freeman|first2 = Mervin|last3 = Ossorio|first3 = Abel|last4 = Coffey|first4 = Hubert |title = The Interpersonal Dimension of Personality| publisher = [[Journal of Personality]], Volume 20, Number 2| pages = 143–161| date = 1951}} Leary suggested there were balanced, healthy forms of behaviour in relation to each of the life scripts and extreme, unhealthy forms of behaviour in relation to each of the scripts.{{cite book| last1 = Leary | first1 = Timothy| title = Interpersonal Diagnosis of Personality: A Functional Theory and Methodology for Personality Evaluation| publisher = The Ronald Press Company| date = 1957| isbn = 9781592447763}}{{cite book| last1 = Wilson | first1 = Robert Anton| title = Prometheus Rising| publisher = Falcon Press| page = 52| date = 1983| isbn = 9781561840564}} 'For instance, a widely used psychological test in this country the Leary Interpersonal Analysis Grid (1957) divides the four quadrants into sixteen sub-quadrants and allows one to grade each in terms of moderate-to-excessive tendency to behave that way.' By the late 1960s psychologists such as [[Eric Berne]],{{cite book| last1 = Berne | first1 = Eric| title = What Do You Say After You Say Hello?| publisher = Corgi| date = 1975| isbn =978-0552098069}} Chapters 3 and 11. [[Thomas Anthony Harris|Thomas Harris]]{{cite book| last1 = Harris | first1 = Thomas| title = [[I'm OK – You're OK]]| publisher = Pan Books| page = 36 to 51| date = 1973| isbn = 0 330 23543 5 |authorlink= Thomas Anthony Harris}} and Claude Steiner{{cite book| last1 = Steiner | first1 = Claude| title = Scripts People Live:Transactional Analysis of Life Scripts| publisher = Grove Press| date = 1990| isbn =978-0802132109}} Chapters 6 to 12. had changed Leary's holistic guide to one which favoured Friendly Strength over all the other scripts. ==Influence on comic book mythology== The author [[Grant Morrison]] later incorporated the idea into his ''[[Invisibles]]'' comic book series (1994–2000){{cite book| last1 = Morrison | first1 = Grant| title = The Invisibles, Volume 7, The Invisible Kingdom| publisher = Vertigo| pages = 31, 34, 192| date = 2002| isbn = 1-4012-0019-2}} and his ''[[New X-Men]]'' comic book series (2001–2004).{{cite book| last1 = Morrison | first1 = Grant| title = New X-Men: E is for Extinction| publisher = Marvel| page = 7| date = 2001| isbn =0-7851-0811-4}}{{cite book| last1 = Morrison | first1 = Grant| title = New X-Men: Imperial| publisher = Marvel| page = 6| date = 2002| isbn = 0-7851-0887-4}}{{cite web| title = New X-Men#114 Annotations| publisher = Deep Space Transmissions| url = https://sites.google.com/site/deepspacetransmissions/annotations/new-x-men/New-X-Men-114-annotations| accessdate = March 8, 2014 }}{{cite web| title = New X-Men#118 Annotations| publisher = Deep Space Transmissions| url = https://sites.google.com/site/deepspacetransmissions/annotations/new-x-men/new-x-men-118-annotations| accessdate = March 8, 2014 }} Morrison has discussed his own views on the hypothesis in his book, ''[[Supergods]]'' (2011){{cite book| last1 = Morrison | first1 = Grant| title = Supergods - Our World in the Age of the Superhero| publisher = Random House| pages = 301 to 307| date = 2011| isbn = 9781400069125}} citing the topic as an influence on his ''[[X-Men]]'' graphic novel, ''[[Riot at Xavier's]]''.{{cite book| last1 = Morrison | first1 = Grant| title = Supergods - Our World in the Age of the Superhero| publisher = Random House| page = 357| date = 2011| isbn = 9781400069125}} "It was the darkside of Spence's imperial youth Stormer generation..." The story's lead character, [[Kid Omega]], develops hostile strength tendencies which run out of control with dire consequences for his school. [[Robert Salkowitz]] discusses the Sekhmet hypothesis in ''[[San Diego Comic-Con International|Comic-Con]] and the Business of Pop Culture'', in which he questions Morrison's take on the hypothesis suggesting instead that the [[Strauss-Howe generational theory]] may explain deeper moods within pop culture.{{cite book| last1 = Salkowitz | first1 = Robert| title = Comic-Con and the Business of Pop Culture| publisher = McGraw Hill| pages = 72 to 73| date = 2012| isbn = 978-0071797023}} ==The four life scripts in relation to atavistic youth trends== [[File:Crass_steve_1981.jpg|thumb|right|Bilious body language: [[Crass]] punk culture, early 1980s.]] [[Image:KellsFol027v4Evang.jpg|thumb|left|A typical early example of an atavistic quaternity, from The Book of Kells.]] The hypothesis suggests that the [[flower children]] of the sixties and the mellow side of [[reggae]] culture presents a collective mood of "friendly weakness" while [[punk subculture|punk]] culture and certain aspects of [[rap]] culture present an archetype of 'hostile weakness'. In the late eighties and nineties, [[rave]] culture along with early [[drum and bass]] supposedly presents a mood based mainly on 'friendly strength'.Spence, Iain (2012). ''The Hare Hypothesis''. Bast's Blend. {{asin|B009E2YUJM}}. Chapter 2 - The Four Life Scripts. The hypothesis suggests that most people are not hard wired to any particular life script and likewise young people are generally fluid enough to move between different pop trends with ease and some humour. Grunge for example is viewed as an atavistic hybrid, drawing on elements of both punk and hippie culture. The social symbolism of the hypothesis is also compared to the archetypal symbolism of Ezekiel's quaternity in the Christian Bible. Ezekiel is said to have had a vision of the winged man (angel), the bull, the lion and the eagle. The same quaternity was later incorporated into [[illuminated manuscript]]s such as the [[Book of Kells]]. Spence has corresponded [[flower power]] and late reggae culture ([[Bob Marley]], [[cannabis]] use, [[dub music|dub]], [[dreadlocks]]) to the gentle angel; the rebellious mood of early rap and punk culture to the sullen bull and the leonine strength of drum and bass and rave culture to the proud lion.Spence, Iain (2012). ''The Hare Hypothesis''. Bast's Blend. {{asin|B009E2YUJM}}. Grant Morrison and Iain Spence have split views on the subject of hostile strength played out through youth culture. Morrison suggests that the trend has come and gone with the film ''[[The Matrix]]'' (1999) along with commanding symbolism in the [[nu metal]] scene. Spence meanwhile suggests that the mood is yet to materialise within pop culture as a major trend but acknowledges that hostile strength symbolism has already emerged through the more commanding aspects of [[hip hop]], [[gabber]] and [[heavy metal music|metal]] sub-cultures. He has criticised Morrison's reference to ''The Matrix'' in relation to the hypothesis suggesting the film is not related to any specific youth trend. Morrison already has a link to the film having influenced the story with his mythology of ''The Invisibles''.{{cite book| last1 = Shapira | first1 = Tom| title = Curing the Postmodern Blues: Reading Grant Morrison and Chris Weston's The Filth in the 21st Century | publisher = Sequart Research & Literacy Organization| page = 84| date = 2013| isbn = 978-0578060767 |chapter=What is The Matrix? |quote="It's also an homage (or a rip off) of much of the content of The Invisibles."}}{{cite web| title = Grant Morrison - Talking with Gods| publisher = Halo 8| date = 2010| url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pKb5jTSBVtU| accessdate = August 17, 2015}} "I think The Matrix owes Grant Morrison everything..." [[Phil Jimenez]].{{cite web| title = Science Fiction's Greatest Stolen Ideas| publisher = [[io9]]| date = 2009| url = http://io9.com/5182390/science-fictions-greatest-stolen-ideas| accessdate = June 29, 2015 }} "Someone who has a bit more standing to accuse The Matrix of copying is Grant Morrison, author of comics series The Invisibles" [[Charlie Jane Anders]].{{cite web| title = 7 Classic Movies You Didnt Know Were Rip-offs| publisher = [[Cracked.com]]| date = 2011| url = http://www.cracked.com/article_19443_7-classic-movies-you-didnt-know-were-rip-offs.html| accessdate = December 29, 2015 }} "The Wachowskis have never acknowledged The Invisibles as an influence, even though they had invited the comic's creator Grant Morrison to contribute a story for their website. Morrison -- who actually liked The Matrix -- says he "was told by people on the set that Invisibles books were passed around for visual reference."". ==The sequential integration of the life scripts== [[File:Babymetalfondatheatrelosangeles11.jpg|thumb|left|[[Babymetal]] - playful commanding symbolism within Pop Metal culture.]][[File:Rave_in_Brooklyn.jpg|thumb|right|Ravers 2010 - wearing children's "kandy" beads, along with teething symbolism.]]The hypothesis suggests that teenagers recapitulate infancy and childhood through pop culture. This self-referencing process supposedly leads to the manifestation of social symbols. Spence proposes that the life scripts start in infancy from the state of friendly weakness, an idea already proposed by Thomas Harris in his book, ''I'm OK, You're OK'' in 1970.{{cite book| last1 = Harris | first1 = Thomas| title = I'm Ok - You're Ok| publisher = Pan Books| page = 42| date = 1973| isbn = 0 330 23543 5}} 'I'm not ok - you're ok: this is the universal position of early childhood, being the infant's logical conclusion from the situation from birth and infancy.' Thomas Harris had split from Eric Berne's view that the scripts start from the stage of Friendly Strength.{{cite book| last1 = Steiner | first1 = Claude| title = Scripts People Live: Transactional Analysis of Life Scripts| publisher = Grove Press| pages = 8–9| date = 1974| isbn = 9780802132109}} There is still some argument as to the sequence and timing of the scripts.{{cite book| last1 = Stewart | first1 = Ian| last2 = Jones | first2 = Vann|title = TA Today – A New Introduction to Transactional Analysis| publisher = Lifespace Publishing| page = 118| date = 1987| isbn = 1 870244 00 1}} Spence has proposed the life scripts evolve in the sequence of friendly weakness (at birth), hostile weakness (infancy), friendly strength and then lastly the commanding behaviour of hostile strength, some time in late childhood. Unlike Harris and Berne, Spence argues that hostile strength does not have to be "demonised or criminalised" as a mood, claiming that it is only one part of a balanced quaternity of behaviour.Spence, Iain (2012). ''The Hare Hypothesis''. Bast's Blend. {{asin|B009E2YUJM}}. Chapter 5 - The Sequential Integration of the Four Life Scripts. In this respect he has returned to Leary's view of approaching the life scripts from a holistic perspective. Timothy Leary himself has also commented on the relationship between infancy and atavistic pop trends.{{cite book| last1 = Leary | first1 = Timothy| title = Chaos and Cyberculture| publisher = Ronin| page = 99| date = 1994| isbn = 9780914171775}} Other writers such as [[Jon Savage]] have applied the same view to punk culture.{{cite book| last1 = Savage | first1 = Jon| title = England's Dreaming, Sex Pistols and Punk Rock| publisher = Faber and Faber| page = 374| date = 1991| isbn = 0 571 16791 8}} 'On the legs were the bondage trousers of claustrophobia and babyish incapacity.' Spence also draws on children's fiction to illustrate the "four timeless scripts" referring for example to the four main characters in ''[[The Wind in the Willows]]'' and the four children in ''[[The Polar Express]]''.Spence, Iain (2012). ''The Hare Hypothesis''. Bast's Blend. {{asin|B009E2YUJM}}. Chapter 6 - The Four Humours: 'Recently the four life scripts have turned up each Christmas with the popularity of, The Polar Express. Lonely Boy presents the friendly weakness of a melancholic, gentle lamb; Know it All Kid is the angry complainer of hostile weakness; Hero Boy is the helpful, protective friendly strength and Hero Girl is the leading child of hostile strength'. ==The Hare Hypothesis== By 2000 Spence had rejected any solar links to the hypothesis suggesting it might best be treated as a psychological puzzle or game. He rewrote a web-site version of his ideas as, The Hare Hypothesis in a move to keep the hypothesis playful and devoid of any solar connection. Grant Morrison revived the original solar link in 2011 in his book ''Supergods'' but didn't offer any scientific evidence in support of his views.{{cite web| title = An Evening with Grant Morrison and Gerard Way| publisher = Meltdown Comics| date = September 12, 2011| url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ERCbo_FSJdU| accessdate = March 20, 2014 }} [[Grant Morrison]] interviewed by [[Gerard Way]]: contains discussion on the early Sekhmet hypothesis. The Hare Hypothesis received a mixed reception on [[Ted Hope]]'s web-site, Truly Free Film, where it was called, 'a fun piece of pop-cultural analysis'. The book was also criticised for having a 'loose [[Jungian]] nature'.{{cite web| title = The Hare Hypothesis|author = Charles Peirce |publisher = Truly Free Film| date = 2014| url = http://trulyfreefilm.hopeforfilm.com/2014/03/nobody-knows-anything-10-the-hare-hypothesis.html| accessdate = July 2, 2015}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sekhmet Hypothesis}} [[Category:Youth culture]] [[Category:Popular psychology]] [[Category:Mythology]]

{{notability|Web|date=November 2013}} {{unreferenced|date=April 2012}}
'''Time for Citizenship''' is a free website, initiated in 1999 by [[Primary education|Primary schools]] in the UK and Ireland. Since then, the site has expanded somewhat and now has a membership of over 4,000 schools. Its central tenets are to teach children to learn: to respect themselves, to respect others’ values and beliefs, to respect their environment, and to respect the law of the land.
Schools interact and share 'best practice' by submitting outstanding projects and children's Artwork. There are currently 38 projects featured on the site from the UK, France, [[South Africa]], Australia, India, Romania, Poland, Spain, Belarus, Greece, Canada, Lithuania, Ireland, Austria, Latvia and Portugal. The site is supported by the Treasury in the UK, [[HSBC]], [[Microsoft]] and [[CSEF]]. Schools and children receive prizes for their entries. A problem page exists for children to pose problems and be answered by their peers - a fine example of [[Mediation|Peer Mediation]].
The site has been endorsed by many of the UK and Ireland's leading politicians.
==External links== [https://web.archive.org/web/20071009212822/http://www.timeforcitizenship.org/ Time for Citizenship]

{{italic title}} '''''Unikkausivut: Sharing Our Stories''''' is a 2011, two-volume DVD boxset, website and educational resource from the [[National Film Board of Canada]] (NFB), bringing together films by and about the [[Inuit]] people of [[Canada]]. The collection traces the development of filmmaking in [[Northern Canada]], from the [[ethnographic film]]s by NFB filmmakers in the 1940s, to contemporary work by [[Elisapie Isaac]] and other Inuit filmmakers.<ref name=Dixon>{{cite news|last=Dixon|first=Guy|title=Out in the cold: the struggle of Inuit film|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/arts/movies/out-in-the-cold-the-struggle-of-inuit-film/article2287215/|accessdate=2 January 2012|newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=30 December 2011}}</ref>
In November 2011, the Government of Nunavut and the NFB jointly announced the launch of the DVD and online collection, which will eventually comprise more than 100 NFB films by and about Inuit available in [[Inuktitut]], [[Inuinnaqtun]] and other [[Inuit languages]], as well as English and French. The boxed set is being distributed to over 50 communities across Northern Canada, with Nunavut's Department of Education supplying ''Unikkausivut'' ([[Inuktitut syllabics|ᐅᓂᒃᑲᓯᕗᑦ]] {{IPA-iku|u.nik.ka.u.si.vut||}}) to every school and library in its territory.<ref name=Unikkausivut>{{cite news|title=Inuit films move online and into northern communities|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/arts/story/2011/11/02/nfb-inuit-film-project.html|accessdate=5 November 2011|newspaper=[[CBC News]]|date=2 November 2011}}</ref><ref name=Nunatsiaq>{{cite news|title=New NFB collection includes 24 films on or by Inuit|url=http://www.nunatsiaqonline.ca/stories/article/65674new_nfb_collection_includes_24_films_on_or_by_inuit/|accessdate=7 November 2011|newspaper=[[Nunatsiaq News]]|date=4 November 2011}}</ref><ref name="Echo">{{cite news | url=http://www.nunavutecho.ca/en/featured-articles/item/4801-gn-and-nfb-launch-unikkausivut-sharing-our-stories-film-collection | title=GN and NFB launch Unikkausivut: Sharing our Stories film collection | work=Nunavut Echo | date=1 February 2012 | agency=Government of Nunavut News | accessdate=March 3, 2012}}</ref>
The film collection premiered in Ottawa on November 2, 2011, as part of the 40th anniversary celebrations of the [[Inuit Tapiriit Kanatami]], followed by community events across Inuit territories (Inuit Nunangat) in [[Iqaluit]], Nunavut on November 7; [[Kuujjuaq]], [[Nunavik]] on November 8; [[Nain, Newfoundland and Labrador|Nain]], [[Nunatsiavut]] on November 17; and [[Inuvik]] in the [[Inuvialuit Settlement Region]] of the [[Northwest Territories]] on November 23.<ref name=NFBpr>{{cite web|title=NFB AND INUIT PARTNERS LAUNCH UNIKKAUSIVUT: SHARING OUR STORIES|url=http://www.onf-nfb.gc.ca/medias/download/documents/pdf/Release_Unikkausivut.pdf|work=Press release|publisher=[[National Film Board of Canada]]|accessdate=2 January 2012}}</ref><ref name=Lampe>{{cite news|title=23 November 2011|accessdate=2 January 2012|url=http://www.cbc.ca/wam/episodes/2011/11/23/wam-november-19-20-unikkausivut/|newspaper=Weekend Arts Magazine|agency=[[CBC Radio]]|format=Audio interview with Johannes Lampe, Minister of Culture, Recreation and Tourism, Nunatsiavut Government}}</ref>
In 2015, the collection was expanded with six films from Nunatsiavut, to mark the 10th anniversary of the Labrador Inuit Lands Claims Agreement. In 2016, the NFB launched a new educational initiative based on ''Unikkausivut''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.rcinet.ca/en/2016/09/19/national-film-board-shares-its-treasure-trove-of-inuit-stories/|title=National Film Board shares its treasure trove of Inuit stories|last=Sevunts|first=Levon|date=19 September 2016|work=[[Radio Canada International]]|access-date=27 September 2016|via=}}</ref>
==Conception== ''Unikkausivut'' was partly inspired by the then-federal [[Minister of Health (Canada)|Minister of Health]] [[Leona Aglukkaq]]. An Inuk from the [[Inuvik Region]], Aglukkaq had enjoyed watching the NFB’s ''[[Netsilik Inuit|Netsilik Eskimos]]'' series in her youth and felt that it would be worthwhile to make these older films about Northern Canada widely available. The NFB, which was already working to make its archival films available on new platforms, reviewed its Inuit film archives and determined that it had over 100 works worth rereleasing.<ref name=Lougheed>{{cite news|last=Lougheed|first=Tim|title=Restoring Cultural Treasures: NFB Project Resurrects Inuit Film Archive|url=http://www.arcticjournal.ca/index.php/2011/07/restoring-cultural-treasures/|accessdate=3 January 2012|newspaper=[[Above&Beyond (magazine)|Above&Beyond]]|date=July–August 2011}}</ref>
==Production== It cost over $1 million and took two years for the NFB to get the first 24 films digitized and ready in all languages; getting all of the films translated for northern communities could cost an additional $2 million.<ref name=Unikkausivut/> This work involves restoring original film prints where necessary, digitization, remixing sound and obtaining rights clearances for new digital formats. Each film must also be dubbed in Inuktitut, the language of one of Canada's four Inuit regions—a challenge in itself, since Inuktitut narrations often run longer than their French or English equivalents. The conversion of all these films is expected to be completed by 2015.<ref name=Lougheed/>
''Unikkausivut: Sharing Our Stories'' was created by the NFB in collaboration with the Inuit Relations Secretariat of [[Aboriginal Affairs and Northern Development Canada]] and the Government of Nunavut's Department of Education.<ref name=theproject>{{cite web|title=The Project|url=http://www.onf-nfb.gc.ca/eng/unikkausivut/?lg=eng|work=National Film Board of Canada website|accessdate=2 January 2012}}</ref> An advisory committee included Inuit elders such as [[Peter Irniq]].<ref name=Unikkausivut/><ref name=Collaborators>{{cite web|title=Collaborators|url=http://www.onf-nfb.gc.ca/eng/unikkausivut/collaborators.php|work=National Film Board of Canada website|accessdate=2 January 2012}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

page.title: University Mobility in Asia and the Pacific

revision.text:
'''University Mobility in Asia and the Pacific''' ('''UMAP''') is a voluntary regional association of government, non-government and/or university representatives of the [[higher education]] sector established in 1993 to enhance cooperation and exchange of people and expertise through increased mobility of higher education students and staff.<ref name="UMAP About">[http://www.umap.org/2009/en/about/index.php UMAP About].</ref><ref name="UMAP Governance">[http://www.umap.org/2009/en/govermance/ UMAP Governance].</ref> UMAP has been endorsed by [[Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation]]<ref>https://internationaleducation.gov.au/About-AEI/Government-Relations/Pages/TheEducationNetwork.aspx</ref><ref>http://umap.org/is/4804/</ref> and member countries are implementing UMAP projects.<ref name="UMAP Brief History">[http://www.umap.org/2009/en/about/index-more3.php UMAP Brief History].</ref><ref>https://www.apec.org/Meeting-Papers/Sectoral-Ministerial-Meetings/Education/2004_education/annex_a</ref>
== History == In 1991 the movement of '''University Mobility in Asia and the Pacific''' ('''UMAP''') was initiated when [[Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee]] proposed and sponsored two conferences to promote the discussion on educational cooperation in [[Asia and the Pacific]], inviting representatives of institutes of [[higher education]] from [[Hong Kong]], [[Japan]], [[Taiwan]] and [[Korea]].<ref name="UMAP Brief History" /> The first meeting was held in April 1991 in [[Hong Kong]] and the second meeting was held in September 1991 in [[Canberra]]. During the second meeting, representatives of 18 countries and territories in the region agreed to establish themselves as a ''Reference Group'', and this was termed the ''First Reference Group Meeting''. Additional annual meetings were held between 1992 and 1996, at [[Seoul]], [[Taipei]], [[Osaka]] and [[Auckland]].<ref name="UMAP Brief History" /> In the fourth meeting, participants called on Member governments to set up a central scholarship fund to encourage mobility in the region and [[Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation]] started publicly supporting UMAP.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Issues Surrounding Mobility with Particular Reference to Japan | author = Yu Kameoka | pages =243–249 |date=June 1996 | journal = European Journal of Education | volume = 31 | issue = 2 | issn = 0141-8211 }}</ref> In the last meeting held in 1996, the location of ''UMAP International Secretariat'' was discussed and decided to establish in [[Japan]]. In 2011, the new location for the International Secretariat was changed to [[Fu Jen Catholic University]] in Taiwan.
===Aims=== "''UMAP aims to achieve enhanced international understanding through increased mobility of university students and staff''".<ref name="UMAP About" />
==UMAP Members== Membership is open to countries/territories in the [[Asia-Pacific]] region. Members can be represented by government, department or minister of education, individual university or university umbrella organization. However, individual persons are not eligible to become members.<ref name="UMAP Members">[http://www.umap.org/2009/en/member/index.php UMAP Members].</ref> * [http://www.umap.org/2009/en/member/ Eligible Countries / Territories] * [http://www.umap.org/2009/en/member/fullmember.php Full Member Countries / Territories] * [http://www.umap.org/2009/en/cms/index.php?gid=8 UMAP participating Universities]
==Governance and Budget== The governing authority is UMAP Board. The board is composed by representatives from each of UMAP Full Members. Each of the Full Members has a voting right, however Secretary General of the Board cannot vote.<ref name="Governance and Funding">[http://www.umap.org/2009/en/govermance/ Governance and Funding].</ref>
Annual budget is prepared in US dollars and UMAP Members need to make a contribution according to the budget. Members can make additional voluntary contribution. These contributions can be funding, facilities or resources.<ref name="Governance and Funding" />
==Exchange== UMAP exchange program is a two-way [[student exchange]] and it is for [[undergraduate]] and [[postgraduate]] students in all disciplines to undertake a minimum of one semester or maximum of two semesters towards their degree in universities overseas, with [[transfer credit|credit transfer]] managed by UMAP and cooperating institutions.<ref name="UMAP About" />
===Home Universities Responsibilities=== * Selection of students and staff * Approval of study program, including any necessary language training * Determine and allocate financial support to participating students and staff * Provide preparatory courses prior to the departure * Recognize work completed overseas for credit towards their degree <ref name="Universities Responsibilities">[http://www.umap.org/2009/en/about/index-more.php Universities Responsibilities].</ref>
===Host Universities Responsibilities=== * Waive tuition fees to participating student and staff * Provide the approved and agreed study program * Evaluate the performance of participants and report to Home Universities * Provide appropriate counseling and support services * Assist students and staff with accommodation * Ensure that appropriate health cover is arranged <ref name="Universities Responsibilities" />
===Exchange Agreements and Funding=== UMAP does not offer individual exchanges, however UMAP countries/territories fund national UMAP programs. Under the agreement between countries/territories, students’ fees are waived and [[transfer credit|credit transfer]] will be made under UMAP credit transfer program. Exchange funding agreements are between the host and home universities. Institution-to-institution agreements covers the maintenance of scholarship benefits, eligibility for government funding assistance and health cover costs.<ref name="Exchange funding">[http://www.usumap.org/ucts_brochure.pdf UMAP Exchange Funding].</ref>
For example, [[Australian universities]] receive A$5,000 per student that applies to UMAP exchange program in order to subsidise the cost of the student’s participation. In addition, universities that receive funding are required to complete a report in order to receive funding from their government. This will vary depending on the agreement between home and host universities, countries/territories.<ref name="UMAP Exchange example">[http://www.deewr.gov.au/International/EndeavourAwards/InternationalStudentExchangePrograms/Pages/UMAPExchangeProgram.aspx UMAP Exchange Funding in Australia].</ref>
==UMAP Credit Transfer Scheme (UCTS)== UMAP has developed a pilot '''[[UMAP Credit Transfer Scheme]]''' ('''UCTS''') to facilitate greater student mobility in the region by providing a framework for establishing credit transfer arrangements.<ref name ="UMAP Credit Transfer Scheme">[http://www.umap.org/2009/en/cms/detail.php?id=6 UMAP Credit Transfer Scheme].</ref> The UCTS objective is to ensure effective [[transfer credit|credit transfer]] for students undertaking [[exchange program]] in universities from UMAP countries/territories.<ref name ="More about UTCS">[http://www.umap.org/2009/en/cms/detail.php?id=133 More about UCTS].</ref>
==Scholarships== During 2002-2005 UMAP provided [[scholarships]] for student in members’ countries/territories universities. However, the program is temporarily closed until further notice.<ref name="UMAP Scholarships">[http://www.umap.org/2009/en/scholarship/scholarship0205.php UMAP Scholarships].</ref>
==Mobility Programs== * [http://www.umap.org/2009/en/cms/detail.php?id=127 Student Connection Online] * [http://www.umap.org/2009/en/cms/detail.php?id=137 Language and Culture Program] * [http://www.umap.org/2009/en/cms/detail.php?id=85 Academic and Research Mobility Forum] * [http://www.umap.org/2009/en/cms/detail.php?id=100 Vice President Forum (2009)] * [http://www.umap.org/2009/en/cms/detail.php?id=29 Alumni Forum]
==Similar program== The [[Erasmus Programme]] (European Community Action Scheme for the Mobility of University Students) is a European Union student exchange program.<ref name="Erasmus Programme">[[Erasmus Programme]].</ref> UMAP and the [[Erasmus Programme]] are regional associations and similarities can be found between these two programs, especially in the [[transfer credit|credit transfer]] and tuition fee waiver scheme where UMAP adopted a similar approach to facilitate student mobility.
There are some differences between these programs.<ref name="UMAP About" /><ref name="Erasmus Programme" /> {| class="wikitable" |---- ! !UMAP !Erasmus |---- |'''Study period''' |One semester to one year||Three months to one year |---- |'''Participants''' |UMAP member/Participating universities||Citizen of one of the countries in the [[Lifelong Learning Programme 2007-2013]] |}
